awd_titl_txt: Mentored Access to Success in Undergraduate Science and Engineering Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to contribute to the national need for well-educated scientists, mathematicians, engineers, and technicians.  The project will provide four-year scholarships to twenty-four low-income, high-achieving STEM undergraduate students with demonstrated financial need at Saint Mary's College of California, a Hispanic-Serving Institution. The Scholars will pursue bachelor's degrees in biochemistry, chemistry, biology, mathematics, or physics.  In the summer prior to their first semester in college, the Scholars will participate in a summer research program. In addition, the Scholars will live in the Science Living Learning Community, participate in a first-year advising cohort, and have access to a peer mentor. Tutoring services will be available in the STEM Center, which is located in the same building as the Science Living Learning Community. As they progress through their collegiate careers, the Scholars will have opportunities to take part in additional summer research programs and to receive funding to present their research at scientific conferences. As seniors, the Scholars will participate in the science career-readiness program developed through a previous NSF award.  Because the College has a high population of underrepresented students, this project has the potential to broaden participation in STEM fields.

The project's specific goals include:  a) providing supports that will enable the Scholar's to graduate with STEM degrees within four years of matriculation and enter the workforce in skilled STEM positions or enroll in graduate/professional school in STEM fields; b) creating a three-week pre-enrollment summer immersion research program and examine its efficacy; and c) evaluating the project and disseminating the results to the scientific community. The project's research component emphasizes analysis of the impact of the pre-matriculation summer research experiences on the Scholar's math placement and subsequent retention, the effects of a holistic support program in the context of a liberal arts and sciences-based curriculum, and the effectiveness of the project's curricular and co-curricular activities in the context of a Hispanic-Serving Institution that is also a private college.  Because of the status of the College as a Hispanic-Serving Institution and the demographics of California, this project has the potential to further expand and diversify the STEM workforce, particularly in the technology-centered San Francisco Bay Area.  This project is funded by the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program, which seeks to increase the number of low-income academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who earn degrees in STEM fields. It also aims to improve the education of future scientists, engineers, and technicians, and to generate knowledge about academic success, retention, transfer, graduation, and academic/career pathways of low-income students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Saint Mary's College of California School of Science

por.por_cntn:
The Saint Mary’s College of California S-STEM program is called Mentored Access to Programs in Science (MAPS). We aimed to recruit three classes of around eight students each and graduate them in four years in a STEM discipline. As part of this program, we offered up to $10,000 of NSF money, and provided institutional funds to guarantee each student a full-tuition scholarship for four years if they stayed within the program and were on course to graduate in a STEM field. Having identified the first year as the crucial retention point for students in science, we created extensive support structures for students as they adjusted to college.

This included a Summer Early Research Immersion Experience (SERIE). Students were paid to attend this program, in the summer prior to their matriculation to Saint Mary’s. Students took life science classes, involving hands-on research experience, as well as a newly developed short course in mathematics that introduced topics in algebra and calculus, from an applied scientific perspective. This math class was popular and was thus adapted into a full semester class taken by incoming first year STEM majors, who would previously have taken a more traditional pre-calculus course. As well as academic endeavors, the SERIE program had a social component, including dinners and outings. We note that, due to COVID in the Summer of 2020, the summer program was online, and the feedback was far less positive. The social aspects were also curtailed in the Summer of 2021. In exit interviews, the class of 2023 was effusive in their praise for the program and the opportunities it provided. The class of 2024 was more ambivalent, having had their first year heavily impacted by the Pandemic.

Of the 20 students we enrolled 14 either have graduated, or are on track to graduate, with a degree in a STEM discipline in four years. A further two student graduated in a non-STEM major, three withdrew from the college and one is planning on completing her major in a fifth year. This four-year STEM graduation rate of 70% and overall rate of 80% is outstanding when compared to numbers that typically graduate. Students at Saint Mary’s do not declare a major until the end of their first year, so we cannot directly compare STEM graduation rates of those students who enter planning on studying science. However, our estimates suggest that approximately 30% of students who matriculate, planning on studying in a STEM discipline actually graduate in one and this is comparable to reported rates nationwide. Given that 100% of students in the program are low income, and 85% are students from underrepresented minority groups, this is even more impressive.

Of those who graduated in the class of 2023 all are studying or working in STEM fields, or those closely related, including one who is in his first year in a PhD. Program in Chemistry at UC Berkeley.

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2024
Modified by: Christopher M Jones
